awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Development and Testing of a Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering Concept Inventory

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to develop and validate a Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering Concept Inventory (FEECI) that will be used as an assessment instrument. Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering (FEE) is a core course in programs offering a BS in Civil and/or Environmental Engineering. The FEECI is being developed as a multiple-choice test that emphasizes conceptual understanding of environmental engineering fundamentals as opposed to rote problem solving. Incorrect answers, or distractors, will be used to capture common student misconceptions. The FEECI is being modeled after the Force Concept Inventory developed by Hestenes et al. for Newtonian mechanics, which has been emulated for similar CIs in statics, dynamics, strength of materials, thermodynamics, signals & systems, etc.

 

The creation of a new instrument requires the gathering of significant amounts of student data and expert opinion in order to identify and then ultimately create items that are representative of the concepts to be measured.  This is where this subaward provided assistance.  This Delphi feature of the ciHUB enables the creation of a blueprint of the targeted conceptual domain and then enables the formation of questions and distractors using an online gathering and vetting system. 

 

The site and virtual community of ciHUB.org grew exponentially and assisted in the assessment of student learning through access of faculty and researchers from all around the world.  At the end of the grant, almost 15,000 users had either used the site as an instructor or a student of a course.  Research has resulted in guidelines on how to develop and implement a better concept inventory in a shorter amount of time.  Educating users as to the benefits and improvements that can occur when critically considering foundational concepts has been an outcome of this funding.  Finally, the site continues to work with others who are interested in using the distribution mechanism for new assessments.


Last Modified: 05/21/2015
Modified by: Teri Reed
